questions.question: A collection of interconnected devices (such as computers, printers, and servers) that can communicate and share resources with each other.
A set of rules and conventions that govern how data is transmitted and received over a network. It defines how devices should communicate with each other.
A networking device that directs data traffic between different networks. It determines the most efficient path for data to travel and helps devices on a local network connect to the internet.
A device that operates at the data link layer (Layer 2) of the OSI model. It connects devices within a local network and forwards data based on MAC addresses.
A basic networking device that connects multiple devices in a network. Unlike a switch, it does not intelligently forward data and instead broadcasts data to all connected devices.
A security device or software that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predefined security rules. It helps protect a network from unauthorized access and threats.
A system that translates human-readable domain names (e.g., www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers use to locate each other on the internet.
A connectionless and less reliable protocol used for faster data transmission when some loss of data is acceptable.
A unique hardware address assigned to network interfaces, such as Ethernet or Wi-Fi adapters. It is used at the data link layer to identify devices on a local network.
A small unit of data that is transmitted over a network. Data is divided into packets for efficient transmission and reassembled at its destination.
A network that covers a small geographical area, such as a home, office, or campus.
A network that spans a larger geographical area, often connecting multiple LANs.
